intro: Camelina edentula, commonly known as the toothless camelina, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many economically important crops such as mustard and canola. The plant is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and linear, glabrous leaves. It typically grows in dry, open habitats and is adapted to arid conditions. Camelina edentula is also known for its potential as a source of oilseed for biofuel and nutritional purposes.
